results.title: Herzberg
results.brief_description: Gerhard Herzberg, winner of a Nobel Prize in 1971, is a molecular spectroscopist. This film shows Dr. Herzberg in his laboratory at the National Research Council in Ottawa where, with the aid of highly sophisticated instruments, he tracks down elusive bits of matter that are the keys to discovering what the planets, stars and the universe are made of.

results.title: Herring gull behaviour
results.creator_credit: James G. Schaadt and Education Development Center
results.brief_description: This documentary charts the life of the herring gull, a seabird. Focusing on its life within its natural habitat, the film looks at such things as the behavioural characteristics of the herring gull. These include: feeding habits, mating rituals, breeding habits etc.

results.title: Herpes: 400,000 new cases each year
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “60 Minutes”.
Describes the physical symptoms and consequences of the disease as well as the emotional trauma it can trigger. Groups of sufferers relate their feelings of hurt, bewilderment, anger and so discuss a highly sensitive and topical subject.

results.title: Heroin
results.creator_credit: Richard Scott, BFA Educational Media and Medi-Cine
results.brief_description: Deals with expectations of drug users, the addiction cycle, the goals, problems, successes and failures of substitutive programs such as methadone therapy. Emphasises through interviews the damaging effects of heroin use. Suitable for upper secondary and tertiary levels.

results.title: Heroic ambitions
results.creator_credit: Channel Four and WNET (Television station : New York, N.Y.)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 7 of Series “Art of the western world”.
Leonardo, Raphael and Michelangelo were so highly regarded by their contemporaries, that they immeasurably raised the status of the artist. Popes and Princes felt honoured to be their patrons, and accorded them the respect and recognition of their equals. Earlier artists could not match the visual power and originality with which these three legendary artists were able to translate their thoughts into images.

results.title: Heroes, heartbreaks and hilarities
results.creator_credit: Denis Phelan, James Murray, Big Fights Olympic Library and Golden Years
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Olympic glory: the golden years”.
The Olympic tradition has not only fostered great sporting champions, it has created immortal images of heroic proportions. Legends such as Johnny Weissmuller, Emil Zatopek, Ron Clarke and many others have become household names, their personalities taking over where sporting achievement leaves off. This is their story - a story of heroes and heartbreak - where athletes are pushed to breaking point and beyond in the struggle for Olympic glory. It is also a look at the lighter side of the Olympic personality and the truth behind the iron-clad determination athletes must present in the heat of competition! Production is based on the “Big Fights Olympic Library”.

results.title: Heroes Unsung
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Last dream: a special report by John Pilger”.
Part One of a three part series which explores aspects of Australia’s history. In this part, John Pilger traces the history of Australian immigration, from a personal perspective, from the horrors of the First Fleet through to the “White Australia” policy and the post-war “Populate or Perish” program. He challenges Australia’s treasured stereotypes and self-image and instead shows the great hardships suffered by certain groups, namely convicts, immigrants, women and Aborigines, in the process of building the nation.

results.title: Heroes of our time
results.creator_credit: Cathy Henkel, Catherine Marciniak, Chris Oliver, Australian Broadcasting Commission and Film Australia
results.brief_description: Greenpeace is one of the largest and most successful of international environmental organisations. By using large-scale direct action operations and an effective manipulation of the media, Greenpeace acts as a constant thorn in the side of multinational companies who pollute the planet. This video concentrates on the organisational structure of Greenpeace Australia, examining how specific campaigns are organised and how recruitment to the organisation occurs. We follow a successful campaign to alert public attention to the polluting of Sydney’s waterways by Caltex Petroleum Company and we follow media and business reactions to the campaign.
